entry.title: Wordlist Story 1
entry.content:
####Chapter one (not finished)
The underground world

Everything changed the day my foster parents took me out of that frigid orphanage, the place was much more a place for contrition than parentless children.

The unidimensional world is not lifeless. If I’m being retentive and still have the mental agility, it could be a long story that may overwhelm you with the details. However, I have such an infamous memory that I may jeopardize the accuracy of the story if I unscrupulously fabricate the parts those seem blurred to me. In order to be dutiful storyteller, it better be terse. Don’t worry, it’s not going to be an insipid one though.

It was about seventy years ago that I got adopted by a couple who are both scientists. I used to be a flabby boy back then and as a result got beaten up a lot by bullies in the orphanage, the Clemency of Jesus state orphanage. This experience may be the cause of the fickleness in my personality since I always felt my future was chancy and devoid of hope. Everything changed the day my step parents took me out of that frigid orphanage, the place was much more a place for contrition than parentless children.

My foster father was a prestigious physicist and Marry, my foster mother, was also a physicist as well as a profound engineer. For a long time, we lived a spartan life in a villa located on the ridge of a dead volcano that its crater is within a hundred yard from our front door. It’s nonthreatening, of course. The alienation from mainstream society could be a boon to someone agoraphobic, but not to an ten-year-old boy. Very soon, my congenital proclivity for exploration was galvanized. One sultry afternoon of August 18th 1946, I had a conversation with my father which lead to the start of our story.

“Papa, are we derelicts of modern society?” I asked in a disgruntled voice.”

“Oh my little Pinsent, where does this platitudinous remark come from?”, my father seems a little surprised as well as amused. He untied the buckle of a machine which was used to irradiate some ore and the experiment stopped. As he turned face to me the glow of the ore ceased in an anticlimactic way.

“Is it because of defamations those vitriolic people spread about you and mama or they trying to encumber your work?” I jump up to papa’s desk, sitting abreast that elaborate machine. “Mama told me that they even excised you from the academy, it’s implausible!” I murmured.

“Son, someday you may realize that being supplanted is not necessarily a punishment but to gain opulent amount of free time. As long as one belongs to a certain organization he has to show conformity, otherwise you might be considered a haughty and immature person.” My father responded in a sedate voice, looked me in the eye. It was like he was trying to engrave this into my head, but then he smiled, with understanding of his son’s boredom, “Do you want to know what this outmoded machine is?”

“What? Outmoded… Then what is it, papa? Who made it?” I couldn’t move away my eyes from that dumbbell-like machine, which seems unworldly that not likely to be created by man. My father was a physicist with talent and towering acadamical achievements, this is one thing. But this machine? It’s just so deviant for a scientific equipment.

“I don’t want to disillusion you, my son. But it was just a gift from an anterior friend. That friend of mine tried to provoke me by sending a thing that nobody knows what it is and where it comes from.” He frowned, “Last several years I was haunted by self-doubt that I may never be able to reveal its inherent nature. Of course I have some hypotheses, but all of them lack of corroboration.”

As far I as can remember, my father never tended to deplore the comic act of his immature friend, in inverse he was so possessed of digging out its secret which seemed undecipherable as if he had a rival to compete with. He had never been such a zealot, but for some time even my mother thought he’s a “strange machine fanatic“. My mother may preserved an appearance of nonchalance, but her insight far transcends my fahter’s. With a cursory glance she drawed a conclusion that this machine must be alien.

“How can you be so sure,” My father asked on dinner table later that day, “You need to do repetitive reaffirmations before repudiating my hypothesis.”

entry.title: c多文件编译的命令行方法（gcc）
entry.content:
之前在学习数据结构的时候（现在还没有学完orz）发现，其实学习到后边的树、图之类的数据结构的时候，经常会用到stack和queue这两个更为基础的数据结构，需要经常性地包含它们的头文件。一直以来都直接用IDE来做这个事情，直到有一天觉得每次做题都要新建一个工程然后添加文件很麻烦，就决定把常用数据结构的.c和.h放在一个文件夹里，题目做完了就把problem.c放到这个文件夹里用命令行编译一下就得了。

其实挺起来好像还是挺麻烦的，不过就当作是增添一项新经验也好。具体做法如下：（以stack.c和stack.h为例）

  1. 把需要一起变一的文件都放入一个directory里边去

  2. cmd/powershell(windows平台)进行如下操作：

    >>> gcc -std=c99 stack.c problem.c -o main

这样在文件夹里就会出现一个名为main.exe的文件了。
